answers.author: John Brooks
answers.text:
It may be feasible depending on the individual. When the Certified Unified Program Agency (CUPA) changes happened in the late 90's an agency I was with at that time investigated the potential of serving as the CUPA for a group of rural counties. Ultimately we did not move forward with that concept and I have not really thought about that program since then. However, here are a few links that may help in chasing down the answer and I also pasted in a code reference indicating that it looks feasible.  Health and Safety Code, Division 104, Part 1, Chapter 4, Article 1, 106625.  The governing body of a local health department may employ on a full-time basis one or more registered environmental health specialists, each of whom shall be a registered environmental health specialist as provided for in this article for the purpose of the enforcement of statutes related to public health, and the regulations of the department, and any local ordinances of a local health department that relate to activities under subdivision (e) of Section106615. This is from http://www.cdph.ca.gov/certlic/occupations/pages/REHS.aspx - Laws & Regulations and you can also check out http://www.calcupa.net/

author: Grant Sparks
text:
I recently received a question regarding consolidated staffing and I'm having a difficult time finding the answer. Any help you be appreciated.
Question: I am attempting to find the regulations and requirements for an Environmental Health Director position. Currently our County has both a Health Officer and an Environmental Health Director. We are looking into the feasibility and legality of having the Health Officer oversee the Environmental Health function (and removing the Director). Can you point me to the regulations that would be applicable?
Note: This individual is from California.
title: Consolidated Staffing Positions - Enviro. Health Director and Health Officer
